data.name: wallenart.dev
content:
This website was built in {{3 days}} using only HTML, CSS and JavaScript with {{no other dependencies}} or tooling than an external API to fetch {{Bible}} verses.
It is a {{100% original UX & UI}} that I built and designed, based on {{terminal user interfaces}} (aka {{TUI}}).

It is also a {{static website}} that is {{completely responsive}}, with a quite distinct {{mobile}} and {{desktop}} UX.
I've always {{loved}} TUI and wanted to give this experience to {{you}}, dear visitor.
I also wanted to {{showcase}} my {{skills}} as a {{full-stack}} developer and {{designer}} by building a {{fast}} and {{responsive}} website that is {{unique}} and {{interesting}} in itself.
I hope you {{enjoy}} your stay and {{come back}} soon! ;)

data.name: npm-dap.nvim
content:
npm-dap.nvim is a {{Neovim}} plugin that I built in order to {{debug}} {{Node.js}} applications using the {{DAP}} protocol through a {{user-friendly}} UI inspired by {{VSCode}}.
It is my first Neovim {{plugin}} already proved quite useful when working with {{Node.js}} in professinal settings.

data.name: ShopiCSV
content: ShopiCSV is my {{biggest personal project}} to date and my second attempt at building software for a commercial purpose.

Originally born as an internal tool in a {{startup}} where I was the only engineer, I {{kept working}} on it in order to take it to the next level and make a proper {{SaaS}} out of it.
Working on this project actually took me on the {{next level}} and made me way more confident in my skills as a full-stack software developer, designer and {{creative}} engineer than I was before.

data.name: nouvell
content:
I started to build nouvell in order to implement a {{newsletter}} for ShopiCSV's presentation website.
After taking a look at the already existing newsletter tools, I found that they were too {{bloated}} for what I wanted to do, since I had to create an account and had to pay if I wanted some functionalities like unlimited subscribers and {{full mail customization}}.

{{What were the challenges}}: Since my project here was to build something {{scalable}} and {{maintainable}} quickly, the main challenge was to juggle between architecture design, forseeing the possible use cases and doing the research about {{Lambda}} and MongoDB while keeping a {{fast-paced development process}}. After {{4 days}} I had a fully functional {{API}} with the possibility to add, remove and edit subscribers, as well as add new products to the {{database}}. More functionalities are to come and I intend to make nouvell a {{viable API}} for those who want to implement their own newsletter {{solution}} (frontend tooling is coming!)

data.name: Buckaroo
content:
Buckaroo was born during the development of ShopiCSV, originally developed as its backend in the span of {{2 weeks}}.
The idea was to provide an {{abstraction layer}} between the frontend and {{AWS S3 SDK}}, making it easier and less error-prone to {{POST}}, {{GET}} and manage files on {{buckets}}.
This was my first experience with {{serverless architecture}}, using AWS Lambda.

{{What were the challenges}}: Buckaroo was actually the part of ShopiCSV's development that I {{enjoyed the most}} and the biggest challenge for me was to let it go, once I had built an API with the {{features needed}} by the frontend. I would have loved to keep {{working}} on it for a couple months, in order to build what I envision for this API to be: a truly {{multi-use}} and {{unopinionated miniservice}}. Buckaroo, as well as its {{SDK}}, is a project I intend to bring to the {{next level}}, with the goal to make it a {{reliable}} and {{trusted}} tool for the developer community.

data.name: Polaris File Explorer
content:
PFx was born during the develoment of ShopiCSV, right after Buckaroo and its {{SDK}}.
I needed an {{intuitive UX}} in order to navigate, {{compare}} and manage files while {{retaining the Shopify aspect}} of the UI.

{{What were the challenges}}:
The main challenge actually arose when I decided to make this a {{standalone tool}}, separating it from ShopiCSV meant making it {{less opinionated}} about the actual content that it will browse, fetch and let the {{user}} manage.

data.name: Plankton Synapse
content:
Based on the contents of a {{rule book}} (the one in the GitHub repo's readme), I had to take care of the {{entire}} project, doing things such as: {{designing}} the game's UX, UI, {{software architecture}}, defining priorities and {{userflow}}.
This project was, at first, built with a standard GUI library ({{GTK#}}) but limitations in said library made me go a {{different route}} and chose a proper {{game engine}}.

{{What were the challenges}}:
In this project, the challenges were {{numerous}}, firstly I didn't have a working computer at that time so I had to {{develop}} the game's logic on a {{small smartphone}} for about {{4-5 months}}, which added lots of productivity and {{debugging}} issues.
Then I was pretty new to Unity and had to follow along {{tutorials}} while developing the game all the while {{managing}} the entire {{project}} with a game designer who wasn't technical at all and not really present, leaving me with the feeling that I was {{working alone}} for many months and doing most of the work on a practical and emotional level.

I am currently rewriting and {{redesigning}} this game {{from scratch}} in {{Go}} using the {{standard library}} and {{Raylib}}. It will feature {{AI}}, {{online mode}} and will be available on {{Steam}} in the {{coming year}} (2024)
